items.title: OpenAI wants to be more than an AI company
items.summary:
- Sam Altman aims for OpenAI to evolve from an AI lab to a major consumer tech company.
- OpenAI is working on a prototype social network for sharing AI-generated images.
- The release of ChatGPT in November 2022 led to rapid growth, reaching 100 million users quickly.
- Altman reported around 800 million users interact with OpenAI systems.
- Future features for ChatGPT include internet search and image generation.
- Altman suggests OpenAI could offer a single sign-on for the web, similar to services provided by other tech giants.

items.title: 8 times Meta has been accused of copying competitors’ features
items.summary:
- Mark Zuckerberg testified in an FTC antitrust trial against Meta, facing accusations of stifling competition through acquisitions.
- A 2012 email chain revealed Zuckerberg discussing buying competitors like Path and Instagram to prevent their growth.
- Critics suggest this reflects a strategy to integrate competitors' features before they can scale.
- Meta's attorney dismissed the FTC’s claims as unfounded and contradictory.
- The article presents eight instances of Meta allegedly mimicking features from other social media platforms, starting with Instagram Stories modeled after Snapchat's feature introduced in 2013.

items.title: Hertz says hackers stole customer data in vendor breach
OpenAI is building an X-like social media network
Zuckerberg defends Meta’s Instagram, WhatsApp deals in U.S. antitrust trial
items.summary:
- Mark Zuckerberg testified in a U.S. antitrust trial regarding Meta's acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp.
- The FTC aims to force Meta to sell or restructure these platforms, claiming they were purchased to reduce competition.
- Zuckerberg argued that the company's focus was on enhancing user engagement, not eliminating competition.

items.title: Bankrupt 23andMe faces scrutiny by U.S. House Committee as government seeks testimony from cofounder
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- A U.S. House committee is investigating 23andMe over the risk of genetic data transfer amid its bankruptcy.
- Committee chairman, James Comer, has scheduled a testimony with cofounder Anne Wojcicki for May 6.
- 23andMe filed for bankruptcy last month due to low demand for ancestry tests, raising concerns about customer data protection.

items.title: Notion Mail lets you build the inbox you actually want
items.summary:
- Notion Mail offers flexibility in organizing your inbox, allowing users to group emails by date, create sections for specific contacts, add notes, or turn emails into action items.
- The app includes an AI labeling feature that sorts emails based on categories like package updates and health-related messages.
- Currently available for Gmail and Google Workspace users on the web and Mac, with an iOS app and support for more email providers coming soon.
- Users can customize their inbox view to display emails based on personal preferences such as sorting by date or specific senders.

items.title: Nvidia reveals it will make AI supercomputers in the U.S. for the first time
items.summary:
- Nvidia announced it will produce AI supercomputers in the U.S. for the first time, utilizing more than one million square feet of manufacturing space in Arizona and Texas.
- The tech company’s investment aims to generate up to half a trillion dollars in AI infrastructure over the next four years.
- Mass production at the U.S. manufacturing plants is expected to ramp up within 12-15 months, creating hundreds of thousands of jobs and significantly boosting economic security.

items.title: Google Hit with Cease and Desist Order in Japan
items.summary:
- Japanese regulators have accused Google of violating anti-monopoly laws.
- Google Japan expressed regret over the cease and desist order, stating investment in Japan promotes innovation.
- The order mandates Google to stop preinstalling its search engine on Android smartphones.
- The Japan Fair Trade Commission's action is the first against a major global tech company.
- Google faced similar legal challenges in the U.S. and Europe, where its dominance has been scrutinized.
- The investigation by Japanese regulators began in 2023, consulting with foreign authorities on similar cases.

items.title: What ‘Ex Machina’ got right (and wrong) about AI, 10 years later
items.summary:
- The article reviews the implications of the film *Ex Machina*, released in 2015, on current AI discussions a decade later.
- The character Nathan Bateman is compared to real-life tech billionaires like Sam Altman and Elon Musk.
- *Ex Machina* foresaw trends in AI conversation and interaction, emphasizing stochastic speech generation now exemplified by ChatGPT and others.
- The portrayal of tech billionaires as unethical in the film aligns with current perceptions of leaders in Big Tech.
- Issues raised by the film about privacy and data usage are echoed in current lawsuits against AI companies for unauthorized data training.
- The notion of AI rights and consciousness is explored, highlighting the ongoing debate in reality versus fiction.
- The article concludes that while Garland's predictions show foresight, some aspects might only be wrong so far, reflecting the ongoing evolution of AI capabilities.

items.title: When will Elon Musk admit he’s bad at gaming?
items.summary:
- Elon Musk projects strength and recently attempted to flex in gaming, claiming to be among the best in Diablo IV.
- He streamed Path of Exile 2, where viewers noted his high rank but poor gameplay; he later admitted to account boosting.
- Despite his efforts, Musk has become a punchline in the gaming community, as demonstrated by a recent rage-quit during a stream after multiple deaths.

items.title: 5 under-the-radar Kindle tricks to elevate your e-reading
items.author: Doug Aamoth
items.summary:
- Kindle offers hidden features for enhanced reading experiences.
- New double-tap functionality allows page turning with a quick tap on side of the device.
- Users can enable the feature after updating to version 5.18.1 through Settings > Device Options.

items.title: OpenAI launches new GPT-4.1 models with improved coding
items.author: Sam Altman
items.summary:
- OpenAI launched GPT-4.1, GPT-4.1 mini, and GPT-4.1 nano models on Monday.
- New models show enhancements in coding, instruction following, and long context comprehension.
- They support up to 1 million tokens and have refreshed knowledge until June 2024.
- GPT-4.1 outperforms GPT-4o by 21% and GPT-4.5 by 27% on coding tasks.
- The models are more cost-effective than GPT-4.5 and will replace the GPT-4.5 preview in July 2024.
- CEO Sam Altman reported positive feedback from developers on real-world utility.

items.title: Uber and Lyft drivers in California could get the right to unionize under this bill
items.summary:
- California Democrats introduced Assembly Bill 1340 to allow rideshare drivers to collectively bargain with companies for better pay and benefits.
- The bill aims to empower over 600,000 drivers and protect them from retaliation for organizing.
- This measure comes nearly five years after Proposition 22 was passed, maintaining drivers as independent contractors.

items.title: Elon Musk and Jack Dorsey want to kill IP law. That would be a huge mistake
items.summary:
- Jack Dorsey tweeted to 'delete all IP law,' supported by Elon Musk.
- Concerns arise about the potential for these views to influence U.S. policy.
- AI ethicist Carissa Veliz highlights changing power dynamics reflected by such tweets.
- Tech companies are lobbying for changes to copyright laws, particularly in the U.K.
- Criticism from creative sectors, with Ed Newton-Rex stating it undermines creators' incentives.
- Public opinion shows a majority favoring greater regulation of AI and protecting creative rights.

items.title: Why you should update your old dating app profile photos ASAP
items.summary:
- More than 50% of young Americans experienced dates with individuals who looked different from their dating app photos.
- 54% of Gen Z and 62% of millennial daters have ended dates early or declined second dates due to mismatched appearances.
- Approximately 10% of daters are unlikely to change their profile pictures even if their appearance changes; however, 84% of women and 83% of men have updated their profiles in the last six months.
- 45% of Gen Z and 33% of millennials believe their profile pictures do not accurately reflect their actual looks.
- A 2023 Pew survey highlights mixed experiences among online daters about their dating app experiences.

items.title: Sony Playstation 5 prices are going up. Here’s where consumers will get hit
TikTok travel influencers are illegally hitching a ride on Mauritania’s Iron Ore Train
America’s loss is China’s gain: Beijing is recruiting fired U.S. scientists
items.summary:
- China is actively recruiting recently laid-off U.S. scientists, particularly in artificial intelligence, to work remotely or relocate to Shenzhen.
- This recruitment coincides with layoffs in U.S. federal agencies like the CDC and NIH, driven by budget cuts.
- U.S. officials express concerns over China's talent programs being potential means to extract sensitive information under the pretext of collaboration.
- Laid-off employees with security clearances are especially vulnerable to these recruitment efforts.
- U.S. agencies are revising layoff protocols and strengthening exit briefings to mitigate risks.
- Shenzhen is portrayed as a neutral scientific environment to attract foreign researchers, along with options for remote collaboration.
- The campaign is part of a broader competition between the U.S. and China for leadership in critical technologies like AI.

items.title: iPhones and laptops are now exempt from tariffs, but Trump’s policy on chips will soon change that
items.author: Mae Anderson, Matt O’Brien
items.summary:
- Recent exemption announced for electronics, including smartphones and laptops, from U.S. tariffs.
- U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick indicated it is temporary, as new tariffs for semiconductors are expected soon.
- President Trump stated that while products are exempt from reciprocal tariffs, they will still face a 20% tariff under national security regulations.
- Electronics exemption intended to benefit major companies like Apple and Samsung; uncertainty around future tariffs may affect stock market for tech firms.
- The exemption could alleviate price pressures on consumer devices but reflects ongoing complexities within U.S.-China trade relations.
- Analysts express concern over the chaotic implications for tech companies planning their supply chains amid possible policy shifts.

items.title: 4 time-saving Microsoft Teams tricks to make you more productive
Quantum computing could change science forever—if it works
How people secured their secrets before encryption
items.author: Jana Dambrogio, Daniel Starza Smith
items.summary:
- Centuries before encryption, people used physical engineering techniques to secure messages.
- Researchers Jana Dambrogio and Daniel Starza Smith discuss letterlocking methods in their new book.
- Dambrogio's work at the Vatican's archives revealed historical security features in documents.
- The pair reconstructed letterlocking techniques used to protect letters and ensure authenticity.

items.title: Section 230 helped create the internet. What happens if it goes away?
items.summary:
- Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, passed in 1996, protects online platforms from liability for user-generated content while allowing moderation.
- Lawmakers, including Sens. Lindsey Graham and Dick Durbin, aim to sunset Section 230 by 2027 to renegotiate its provisions, with a press event expected before April 11.
- Repealing Section 230 could lead to increased censorship and a chilling effect on innovation and free expression, as platforms may restrict critical content to avoid liability.

items.title: Inside ‘Signalgate’: How The Atlantic navigated a national security scandal
items.summary:
- Government officials accidentally included Jeffrey Goldberg, The Atlantic’s editor-in-chief, in a Signal chat discussing U.S. military plans.
- CEO Nicholas Thompson discusses the scandal known as 'Signalgate' and its implications for the publication's editorial independence.
- Substantial increase in subscriptions as more people trust the brand; advertising remains complicated due to political tension.

items.title: This great free tool brings Pixel-quality image sharpening to any device
items.summary:
- Introduction of a new web app called [Unblur Image Online](https://unblurimage.ai/) that sharpens images effortlessly.
- Highlights the evolution of image editing tools, making advanced adjustments accessible to everyone.
- Encourages readers to explore free tools without needing expensive software or expertise.

items.title: Steve Jobs was probably the last beloved tech leader the world will ever have—and that’s a good thing
items.summary:
- Steve Jobs was referred to as a 'rock star CEO' by an Apple employee nearly 23 years ago.
- The author reflects on their time at Apple, noting the fascination people had with Jobs.
- After observing the impact of technology on society, the author believes Jobs will be the last universally beloved tech leader, a sentiment they consider good.

items.title: What it means to be an AI-augmented leader
items.author: Rasmus Hougaard, Jacqueline Carter
items.summary:
- AI can transform leadership and work by enhancing awareness, wisdom, and compassion.
- Leaders using AI can delegate tasks, improving human connection and performance.
- AI-augmented leaders will replace those who do not adapt to AI technologies.
- Example of Ellyn Shook from Accenture shows how AI can enhance rather than dehumanize leadership tasks.
- The insights are based on the book "More Human: How the Power of AI Can Transform the Way You Lead."

items.title: ‘Build up your emergency fund’: Millennials are sharing recession survival tips on TikTok
items.summary:
- Millennials are sharing recession survival tips on TikTok amid fears of economic collapse.
- Content creator Itzett Romero emphasizes preparing for recessions rather than panicking, advising followers to form alliances for shared expenses.
- TikTok user @yaptrapped suggests friendship as a means to survive financially, echoing shared tips.
- Financial advice includes building an emergency fund to cover three to six months of living expenses.

items.title: The next big AI shift in media? Turning news into a two-way conversation
5 things to know about Meta’s upcoming FTC trial
items.summary:
- Meta faces an antitrust trial with the FTC on Monday.
- The trial could force Meta to divest Instagram and WhatsApp, which are crucial to its advertising revenue.
- The FTC argues that Meta’s acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp were aimed at eliminating competition, harming users and market quality.

items.title: Trump’s billionaire pick to lead NASA sparks debate over the future of space exploration
items.summary:
- Jared Isaacman, nominated for NASA administrator, faced Senate confirmation questions on April 9, 2025.
- If confirmed, he will be the first billionaire and the first with ties to the commercial space industry to lead NASA.
- Isaacman has a background in aviation and business; he founded the payment processing company Shift4 and held a record for a round-the-world flight in a light jet.

items.title: iPhones made in the USA? Here’s why that won’t happen, even with Trump’s tariffs on China
items.summary:
- Trump's tariffs on China are expected to be significant, with current tariffs at 145% on products made in China.
- Analysts suggest moving iPhone manufacturing to the U.S. is unrealistic because it would cost billions and significant price increases would ensue, potentially tripling the iPhone price.
- Apple CEO Tim Cook has raised concerns about the available skilled labor in the U.S. to handle necessary manufacturing tasks.
- The tariffs have already impacted Apple's stock price, dropping by 15% and reducing its market value by $500 billion since April 2.
- Apple's current profit margins, largely driven by services, allow it to absorb some tariff costs temporarily without raising product prices.

items.title: Google lays off hundreds, impacting Android and Pixel teams
items.summary:
- Google laid off hundreds of employees in its platforms and devices unit.
- The layoffs affect the Android platform, Pixel phones, and Chrome browser.
- The move follows earlier buyout offers to employees in the unit made in January.
- A spokesperson mentioned the layoffs are part of efforts to operate more effectively.
- Other tech companies like Meta, Microsoft, and Amazon have also made recent layoffs.

items.title: Venmo’s dubious defaults look like a permanent privacy foul
items.summary:
- Venmo's default setting of making users' friends lists public has sparked significant privacy concerns.
- Vice President JD Vance and others have been outed for their public Venmo accounts, revealing connections to various industry figures.
- A report identified over 50 lawmakers and Trump administration officials with public friends lists on Venmo, raising serious privacy implications.

items.title: Why I read 597 applications for one job—no AI involved
items.summary:
- The author posted a job description for a chief of staff role at Graham & Walker, receiving over a hundred applications in an hour.
- Overwhelmed by interest, the author considered using tools for efficient review but was moved by an applicant's comment about the dehumanizing job application process.
- The author chose to read all 597 applications personally, stating that it was time well spent and an unforgettable experience.

items.title: This tiny screw is powering the humanoid robot revolution
items.summary:
- The humanoid robotics revolution is nearing mass adoption, with robots already working in factories globally.
- Traditional ball screws are being replaced by planetary roller screws, offering better durability for humanoid robots.
- The market for planetary roller screws is estimated at $1.8 billion and expected to grow over 30% annually in the next five years.
- Actuators are crucial for converting rotary motion to linear motion in robots, enhancing their functionality.
- The cost of planetary roller screws and actuators is high, accounting for about 33% of a humanoid robot's total material costs.

items.title: IPOs are being pulled and the market is yo-yoing. What’s next?
items.author: Chris Morris
items.summary:
- Major volatility on Wall Street with the Dow swinging almost 3,300 points in five days.
- Over a dozen companies have shelved IPO plans, including StubHub and Klarna.
- Mergers and acquisitions also significantly down in Q1, lowest since Q2 2020.
- Market unpredictability driven by tariffs and other factors is causing concern.

items.title: Silicon Valley needs to get back to silicon
items.summary:
- The article discusses the historical significance of the 'traitorous eight' who founded Fairchild Semiconductor, marking the beginning of Silicon Valley's innovation era.
- It emphasizes the importance of hardware in technological progress and contrasts it with the current state of predominantly software-driven innovations.
- The author advocates for a return to tangible hardware innovations that can truly change the world, highlighting the recent release of Nvidia's powerful DGX Spark desktop computer as a potential turning point for personal computing.

items.title: Morocco’s social security database hacked and leaked on Telegram
items.summary:
- Morocco’s social security agency confirmed a cyberattack that resulted in a data leak on Telegram.
- Data stolen includes personal information used for pensions and insurance benefits.
- Hackers claimed the attack was retaliation for alleged Moroccan harassment of Algeria on social media.
- The incident is viewed as part of an ongoing cyberwar between Morocco and Algeria, with relations between the countries deteriorating.
- Leaked documents include sensitive salary information and unverified financial data on executives and political figures in Morocco.

items.title: Trump’s revenge politics has a new target: the cybersecurity official who defied him in 2020
items.summary:
- President Trump ordered an investigation into former CISA head Chris Krebs, targeting his actions during and after the 2020 election.
- Trump directed Attorney General Pam Bondi and Secretary of Homeland Security Kristi Noem to review Krebs' activities and possibly revoke his security clearance.
- Krebs was fired in November 2020 for stating that President Biden won fairly, opposing claims of electoral fraud.
- The memo labels Krebs as a "significant bad-faith actor" and aims to strip security clearances from SentinelOne employees related to this issue.
- SentinelOne, where Krebs is currently chief intelligence and public policy officer, stated it would cooperate with the review but does not expect significant impact on its operations.
- This action is part of Trump's broader strategy of punishing those who oppose him, having previously rescinded security clearances from various individuals and groups.

items.title: DOGE just announced more layoffs at TTS, the government’s vaunted tech group, sources say
items.author: Thomas Shedd
items.summary:
- Thomas Shedd announced layoffs at Technology Transformation Services (TTS) during a conference call.
- Existing employees must reapply for roles, potentially with new descriptions and lower pay.
- TTS workforce, originally 691, aims to be reduced by half, affecting at least 120 employees.
- Shedd's email indicated a shift to smaller, flexible teams for government-wide services.
- TTS has been responsible for key government websites and systems.
- DOGE has previously dismantled the U.S. Digital Service and 18F, further impacting TTS resources and purpose.

items.title: What if Apple Vision Pro’s killer app is the ‘AI girlfriend’?
items.summary:
- The concept of the "AI girlfriend" is becoming a reality as interest in digital companionship grows in 2025.
- Generative AI can simulate emotional intimacy, responding to user quirks and challenges.
- Apple's Vision Pro headset aims to project digital partners in immersive augmented reality, potentially transforming how users engage with AI companions.
- Research indicates that AI interactions could become addictive, possibly leading people to prefer them over human relationships.
- Apple currently restricts adult content on its platforms, but the demand for immersive AI companionship is rising in the market.

items.title: Silicon Valley is pushing Trump to make Greenland a ‘Freedom City’
items.summary:
- Silicon Valley investors promote Greenland as a site for a libertarian 'freedom city' with minimal corporate regulation.
- The idea is supported by Ken Howery, Trump's pick for Denmark ambassador, who will lead Greenland-acquisition negotiations.
- Greenland is seen as a hub for AI, autonomous vehicles, space launches, and more, reflecting a push for low-regulation cities globally.

items.title: Apple airlifted 600 tons of iPhones from India to the U.S. Here’s why
What the ‘Bhagavad Gita’ can teach us about AI
items.author: Faisal Hoque
items.summary:
- The author tested a large language model's understanding of the Bhagavad Gita, observing its structured yet impersonal responses.
- AI can analyze philosophical texts but lacks the lived experience and emotional depth that true wisdom requires.
- The article explores the philosophical implications of AI as technology interweaves with human experiences, highlighted by the author’s personal story involving his son's cancer diagnosis.
- The dilemma faced by Arjuna in the Bhagavad Gita serves as a metaphor for the moral complexities of AI and human action.

items.title: How Camb.ai is breaking language barriers with AI
items.author: Avneesh Prakash, Akshat Prakash
items.summary:
- Camb.ai, founded in 2022, aims to disrupt English dominance in global media with AI-powered real-time translation.
- The platform processes content up to 20 times faster than traditional dubbing services.
- Major League Soccer uses Camb.ai’s technology for live broadcasts; demand has also arisen in video advertising and smart toy localization.
- Camb.ai has raised $15.5 million and supports translations in over 150 languages, including rare languages like Maleku.
- CEO Avneesh Prakash and CTO Akshat Prakash co-founded the company, leveraging their backgrounds in biometric ID systems and AI engineering.

items.title: How video games became peak IP
items.summary:
- The *Minecraft* movie has grossed nearly $163 million in its opening weekend despite poor reviews.
- In 2023, the *Super Mario Bros. Movie* surpassed $1 billion at the box office, and Amazon’s *Fallout* had 2.5 billion viewing minutes in its first week.
- Video games are no longer seen as commercial failures in Hollywood, evolving into a profitable source of intellectual property for studios.

items.title: ‘Somebody has to pay the cost’: Business owners break down tariff drama on social media
Tesla is launching sales in Saudi Arabia, where the obstacles do not (yet) include Musk protests
